dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’m in meetings all day. I get to see so little of the city.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I think people here do have concerns. About the trial.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I have concerns myself.

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: The community’s very keen to support you.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’m glad to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: But we’re also interested to know what you’re thinking.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BRENNER
dialogues.text: Mr Julius is a very brilliant young man. Can we speak frankly? There’s a fear you may have fallen under his spell. From the end, an older woman, JANINE STONE speaks robustl

dialogues.speaker: JANINE
dialogues.text: You won't be the first woman to be attracted to his intellect. Diana. Some crude laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 34.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: So far, I’ve raised most of my * costs back home. *

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And was that easy?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It wasn’t difficult.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BRENNER
dialogues.text: Not as difficult as in London, is that what you’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s a principle and I’ve stuck to * it. No single source of finance. * One man offered to pay for the * whole thing. But when the history * of this moment comes to be written, * I think it’s important many people * gave, not one. * There are uneasy looks up and down the table.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You talk about history. Look at it from our point of view. We live with David Irving. He’s British. He’s a has-been. What’s a trial going to do? It’s going to give him a new lease of life.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I can’t help that. I didn’t bring the prosecution. He did.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, but you could prevent the whole thing from happening.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: How would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Settle. I mean it. Sign some piece of paper. Is that so terrible? He's never going to give you Auschwitz. OK, but then he’s David Irving. We've lived with worse.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And what do you want me to settle for? Four million dead? Three? One? What are you comfortable with? DEBORAH looks at him, not yielding.  51 52 53 54 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 35.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I may say so, Mr Irving thrives on exactly this kind of blackmail. If you’re Jewish, keep your head down, lay low, and be grateful. Here in England, you may like appeasement, but I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI BRENNER
dialogues.text: I don’t think you should be using a word like appeasement.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t I? Then what word should I use?

dialogues.speaker: SONIA
dialogues.text: All we're saying: beware of Anthony Julius. He does these things for his own glory. Other women have been in his pocket and they’ve found it an uncomfortable place to be.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Well if it’s pockets we’re talking about, perhaps you can explain why the British find them so hard to open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi swooshes past on the wet street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH is lying in bed, unable to sleep. She turns over few times. Then she throws back the covers and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH, in track suit, slips out of the small entrance a the side and runs off down Picadilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH runs along by the Houses of Parliament, Westminst the river Thames. She comes to the statue of Boadicea, th heroic warrior queen on the south corner of Westminster Bridge. She stops and looks up at it, angry. The sound of next scene laps over.  55 56 57 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 36.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I had a hellish night, I couldn't sleep. I was so angry. EXT. FLEET STREET. DAY Os, JULIUS, DEBORAH and LAURA, all in coats, are coming quick along a busy pavement. Roaring traffic. Gusty wind.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Oh really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I had dinner last night with leaders of the Jewish community.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: The community, eh? And did they tell you it would suit them better if you dropped the case?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I was defending you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Were you? Well I’m sure you did a very good job. Perhaps you should take it up professionally. JULIUS throws an amused look, picking up on her tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contrasting calm. They have entered a fine square of 18th century terraces, with staircases like an Oxbridge colleg

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: They seem to think you're taking over this case for your own glory.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Glory? Goodness. I hadn’t thought about glory. Fascinating. What on earth did they give you to eat? He dives through a darkened arch and up a staircase. INT. RAMPTON’S CHAMBERS. DAY 57 A Dickensian rabbit-hole of papers, legal bundles. A roar coal fire. A powdered horse-hair wig on a stand, an elabo black silk robe on a hanger. A desk in the corner, largel innocent of technology. RAMPTON is standing with a comput mouse in his hand. He’s a white-haired upper-class Scot, avuncular, 60s, with gold-rimmed glasses.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 37.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I don’t understand this thing, I really don’t... Beside him is HEATHER, 30s, glasses, plain suit, no-nonse

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Deborah Lipstadt, this is Richard Rampton. RAMPTON reaches out to shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: ‘Bha, ‘tis the author of our misfortune...’ Come in, please do. Warm yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Richard’s your leading counsel.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: I’ve explained to Deborah the difference between barrister and solicitor. Our legal system seems forbidding but it works.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: If your legal system worked, I wouldn’t be in this mess. I don’t mind Dickensian, it’s Kafkaesque I’m worried about. RAMPTON throws an amused glance at JULIUS.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: And this is our junior counsel, Heather Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Hello, Heather.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: How are you? RAMPTON has an already-open bottle of good Burgundy, and contrasting plastic glasses.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I’ve opened a decent red. You don’t mind plastic, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: I’m not going to drink, Richard, I haven’t eaten. And Deborah hasn’t slept.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 38.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I‘1ll taste the wine. Why not? Everything else is being decided for me. RAMPTON smiles, loving this reply. He sees DEBORAH taking towers of books about World War Two and the camps.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed, Heather and I have been introducing ourselves to the subject.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I can see.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: A little light reading... LAURA has replied to RAMPTON’s mimed offer of wine with a smile of assent. DEBORAH is looking at a picture of RAMPT in fly-fishing gear.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You ever catch anything?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: From time to time. Then she looks at his books. A German dictionary.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You don’t speak German?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Ah! Like a barrister. Straight to my weakest point. I do know the libretto of The Magic Flute, that’s the only German I have. Probably of little use in the forthcoming encounter. Cheers!

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Cheers! RAMPTON smiles broadly. His manner is feathery.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I was hoping to get on with writing my life of Mozart, but I see I shall have to postpone again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Richard is the most skilful advocate in the country. I don’t mind saying it. But RAMPTON has sat down with his wine, grave.  58 59 60 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 39.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: In this case, I wish I thought skill were enough.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What will it need then?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: A rarer quality.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Appetite. RAMPTON is sombre. The room goes quiet. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Plainly I shall have to go to Auschwitz. I hope you’1l be kind enough to accompany me.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why do you need to go? RAMPTON lights a Gitane and looks a moment, impenetrable.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Legal reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water drips from one of the iron letters of the arched message ‘Arbeit Macht Frei.” The flat space beyond the arrival area is completely deserted. Mist. Barbed wire is faintly detectable, not much else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge masses of spectacles, artificial limbs, children’s shoes, suitcases, chamber pots and 80,000 single shoes. RAMPTON has a small Leica. He is taking flash photos thro display cabinet windows, his expression intense, unreadab He winds the camera on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the Crematorium ruins, in wasteland, DEBORAH is in sneakers, near HEATHER. A little way off, PROFESSOR ROBER JAN VAN PELT, thin, boyish, in black leather jacket, blac polo neck, black jeans. His hair is dyed blonde. His rese assistant, OMER ARBEL, has large files of papers. There i long silence. It’s cold. No-one wants to be there.  61 62 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 40.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Is he coming? He wants us here, and then he doesn’t show up.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: He’s late, that’s all. He’s often late.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Is he late for court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMPTON stands alone in the mist. He has a small tourist and a pocket compass. He looks at the map, then deliberat starts pacing. Watch-towers and fences loom around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is waiting as RAMPTON approaches through the mi He is still pacing. DEBORAH watches. RAMPTON stops and ma a note, then continues towards them.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Good morning, everyone. You must be Professor van Pelt?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Good. Then let’s get down to business. Deborah. Heather. They have shaken hands. RAMPTON seems to want to move on. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Professor?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I suggest we start by taking a walk round the perimeter fence.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I just did that. ROBERT JAN stands, slightly taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Good. Then let’s look at the plans. Omer? ARBEL opens the file and takes out the papers. Everyone gathers round to look.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 41.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to understand the scale of the operation. What you’re looking at here is one of the largest and most efficient killing machines in human history.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Yes, we know what it is. It’s how we prove what it is, that’s what we're interested in. We’re not here on a pilgrimage, we’re here to prepare a case. DEBORAH throws a glance to HEATHER who remains impassive. gestures to the map and to the pile of rubbish and bricks

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: This is where we are. This is Crematorium II. The buildings were deliberately demolished by the Germans in the autumn of 1944 to destroy the evidence of what they did here. They dynamited them again one week before the end of the war. ROBERT JAN leads the group to the top of a small set of b steps. They peer down in the rubble and broken concrete.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These steps led down into the undressing room. The Olere drawings please. ARBEL opens the drawings. They are in graphite pencil and very precise.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: David Olere was a French artist. A survivor. He was able to draw a lot of what he’d seen. ROBERT JAN points to the ruined steps, matching those in drawing. ROBERT JAN runs his finger along as they walk al the brick edge of the ruins.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The victims walked down into the undressing rooms. Then they were led through here, past a sign that said ‘To the Baths’ and into the gas chamber here. They have come to the edge of a large mass of crumpled an shattered concrete. ROBERT JAN climbs cautiously onto the remains of the roof. The others follow.  63 64 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 42.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please watch your step. Tread carefully. This is a shrine. What we are standing on is all that remains of the gas chamber itself. This was the roof. The chamber was right under here. The doors were locked and cyanide crystals - Zyklon B - were poured in on them through holes in the roof. They all look round the rubble at their feet. No-one spea As RAMPTON turns to go, he trips on something sharp.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Shit! The others turn, shocked. To cover the moment, RAMPTON li a Gitane. He gestures the others to move on. RAMPTON pull something from the sole of his shoe - a rusty twist of ba wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at a bare-brick building. RAMPTON impatiently lights a second cigarette from the stub of the first.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Now here are the delousing chambers. Typhus was a terrible problem at the camp and the lice that carried it had to be destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Ah good, now we get to it. We need to talk about Leuchter.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I’m coming to Leuchter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group comes into the building.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: This is the building in which the prisoners’ clothes were deloused. They used Zyklon B for that too. To kill the lice.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: We know that?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Yes.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 43.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: For sure? You can prove it? We can’t take anything for granted. I’m going to need to see the proof.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I can give you proof. ROBERT JAN produces a copy of the Leuchter Report.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, in February 1988, a Holocaust denier called Ernst Zundel sent Fred Leuchter, an engineer and self-styled execution expert, from America to test in different parts of the camp for evidence of traces of poison gas in the brickwork. He brought a camera- man with him to document what he found.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’ve seen the footage. ROBERT JAN puts his hand on the wall, as if to feel it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: He was testing for levels of hydrogen cyanide. HCN. Look, the blue stains. Here. And here.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: He came with a chisel.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And hacked away...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: .--illegally, without the permission of the authorities...

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: .-+. and then smuggled the pieces out of Poland in his suitcase. Wrapped in his dirty underwear. DEBORAH is fierce, indignant. RAMPTON just looks.  There’s a Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 44,

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Be that as it may. We can criticise his methods, but it’s his conclusions we have to discredit.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: He found higher levels of HCN here in the delousing chambers than he did in the gas chambers themselves. From this he concluded that no human beings were killed at Auschwitz. Only lice were killed. silence. DEBORAH shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Why are we wasting our time? Leuchter’s not worth the paper it’s written on.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: So you say. You have to say why.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Well of course he found higher concentrations in here. Think about it: It’s exactly what you’d expect. It takes over twenty times more cyanide to kill lice than it does human beings. Twenty times! Leuchter didn’t even know that! RAMPTON still seems annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: The whole thing’s infuriating.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: It beggars belief. Why has no proper scientific study been done of the whole site? By reputable scientists? Fifty years on? It’s ridiculous. It’s unprofessional. Where’s the proof? Where’s the evidence? I need to know that.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why do we need a study? We have the evidence. DEBORAH is furious. RAMPTON looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I need to ask some more questions. Are you happier outside?  65 66 67 68 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH is standing by herself, pacing. HEATHER is a litt way off. Some time goes by. Inside RAMPTON can be heard s aggressively arguing small points with ROBERT JAN.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I thought we weren’t going to try the Holocaust.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: We're not.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: We’re not going to debate ‘Did the Holocaust happen?’ That’s what we agreed. There is a silence. DEBORAH paces.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what we agreed!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: He’s asking questions. That’s all. He has to ask questions. This is not about memorialising, it’s about forensics.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Do you know how many people died here? And he’s asking questions about what really happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAMPTON, still going at it inside with ROBERT JAN, has tu to listen. The sound of DEBORAH’S anger drifting across t him, discernible but indistinct. He looks at ROBERT JAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. DEBORAH walks back alone to the remains of Cremato II. She stands, looking at the steps down to the rubble. closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her mind's eye, a great mass of women's feet staggerin down the steps that led to the undressing room. Glimpsed between the legs, a small girl’s terrified face - like a young RACHEL BLOCH. No longer than a second or two. Then  69 70 71 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH bows her head.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: God, full of mercy, who dwells in the heights, Provide a sure rest upon the Divine Presence's wings, Within the range of the holy, pure and glorious, Whose shining resemble the sky's... Hearing a voice join in beside her, DEBORAH looks to find ROBERT JAN. He takes out a yarmulka from his pocket. They exchange a look, then lower their heads and together star the prayer again, this time in Hebrew. El Molei Rachamim. Some way off, RAMPTON appears, looking towards them, sile thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old town centre. The grim little GROUP, carrying thei bags, move across to their hotel. From the church towers, trumpeter sounds the hour from the belfry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH in the corner at a basic wooden table. HEATHER an ROBERT JAN at another banquette. RAMPTON appears above he with a chilled bottle of vodka and two shot glasses.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I brought you a drink. I thought you might need one.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Thank you. I do. He sits down and pours, saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you get what you wanted from the visit? RAMPTON looks up, stopped by her hostility.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Deborah, you mustn’t characterise me without feelings. I have feelings.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What did you feel today?  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 47.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Shame. RAMPTON pushes the glass across to her with one finger. RAMPTON (CONT’D) I have a terrible fear that if I'd been asked to draw up those plans, I might have agreed. Out of sheer weakness.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: That’s honest of you to say so.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Just a fact. The world is full of cowards and I’m one of them. There’s a line of Goethe’s. “Der Feige droht nur, wo er sicher ist.” “The coward only threatens when he feels secure.”

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I thought you didn’t speak German. RAMPTON shrugs, modest.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've learnt German? In the last year?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: How else was I to master the documents? Irving has a forty-year start on me. I’ve had to try and catch up.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And have you?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: No. There is a trace of self-mockery in this chilly exchange. RAMPTON pours two more shot glasses. RAMPTON (CONT’D) We'll get a trial date soon. Nine- tenths of court craft is preparation. DEBORAH looks at him a moment, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You haven’t taken my statement yet.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: No. No, I haven’t.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Anthony hasn’t talked to you? DEBORAH shakes her head. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Very well. We made a couple of decisions.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: First, we decided we don’t want to put the case before a jury. We think it’s safer to do it before a judge.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: A single judge?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Everything depending on one man? Is that a good idea? RAMPTON shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: We’re worried about what antics Irving might get up to with an audience of twelve.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’m surprised it’s our choice.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: It’s not. We have to get Irving to agree.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Oh. We have a notion. RAMPTON smiles to himself. DEBORAH doesn’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And the other one?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Sorry? 48.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 49.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: A couple of decisions, you said.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Oh yes of course. RAMPTON looks at her, absent for a moment. RAMPTON (CONT’D) We decided... Anthony and I both think it would be better if you didn’t testify.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: That’s it. We don’t believe you should testify. There is a silence. DEBORAH is fixed on him. Then DEBORAH reaches and pours herself another shot.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s me...

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s me he’s chosen...

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I’m aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Of all the people who’ve written about him, David Irving has targeted me. I have to defend myself.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Of course. I know that’s how it seems. But. He stops, reluctant to go on.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What? I sit at my trial every day, I listen to my reputation being destroyed - someone attacks me, attacks my work, my profession, my integrity, and I say nothing? Is that the idea? RAMPTON opens his hands as if to say ‘Yes, that’s it.’  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 50.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why? Because you don’t trust me?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You think I might get emotional?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: On today’s evidence...

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: We were at Auschwitz, Richard. But RAMPTON looks right back at her.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I remind you: I teach, I lecture, I talk to the press...

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I order ideas. That’s what I do. That's what I’m good at. You think you need to protect me?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I’m not protecting you, I’m protecting our case. Our strategy is to keep the focus on Irving and Irving alone. The trial is not a test of your credibility, it’s a test of his. DEBORAH looks at him, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You don’t think I’m good enough.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I haven't said that. Irving's an expert. He's a scholar.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And I’m not?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: You're in a different field. You're not a historian of the Third Reich. RAMPTON waits. It’s on a knife-edge. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Represent yourself. Go in the box. Why not? Irving will be delighted. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 51. RAMPTON (CONT’D) He’s got a huge dossier. Everything you ever said or did. It’s what he’s always wanted. To get his hands on you and tear you apart.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And no doubt you think he’d succeed? You don’t trust me. RAMPTON is inscrutable, knowing this is a decisive moment

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Everything you have to say you said in your book. Our task is to starve Irving. Putting you on the stand would feed him. The trial’s happening to you, but it’s not about you.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: This man hates me. He's coming for me. It’s personal. When someone hates you, you take them on. Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what people will say.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I do.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: They’1l say I’m a coward. “She didn’t dare go into the box, because she knew she would lose.”

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: You're right. They will say that.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’ll have to live with that.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. That’s the price you'll pay for winning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The imposing facade. Underneath:

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr Julius, is there any other housekeeping we need to do before we close the pre-trial hearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 73 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room. Almost informal, just a single JUDGE, JOHN TRENCH, 60s. IRVING, now 61, at one table, JULIUS at anot in suit and tie, with LIBSON behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Just one question, my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: On our side, we're beginning to feel that for the layman this particular subject may represent an impossible challenge.

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: I see. You’re asking to dispense with a jury?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: We are, my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: Have you asked Mr Irving his views? Mr Irving? IRVING stirs, uncertain. But JULIUS modestly interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Perhaps, before Mr Irving speaks?

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: We all know: Mr Irving has devoted his life to the study of the Third Reich. I admit myself to having sometimes struggled with the demands of the material. I wonder if Mr Irving really believes that it’s fair to ask the regular Joe or Joan who walks in from the street to grasp in a mere few weeks what he himself has taken a life-time to master. IRVING is looking at him. Which way will be jump? Then:

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: I agree. The issues before the court are sufficiently complex to require the attention of a learned judge, and too complex to confront a jury with.  74 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Mr Irving?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Quite sure. JULIUS looks, his bluff perfect.

dialogues.speaker: TRENCH
dialogues.text: A trial by judge alone it is then.

74 DEBORAH is unpacking - unfamiliar adaptor plugs, guide bo She's thought of everything. Then a framed photo of herse with The Mutt goes in pride of place. DAVID IRVING is on doing a respectful studio interview.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING, (TV)
dialogues.text: Naturally, I’m delighted this case is finally coming to court.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (TV)
dialogues.text: You're representing yourself?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING, (TV)
dialogues.text: I have the advantage that although I don’t know the law, I do know the topic. It would cost me half a million pounds to hire professional representation. And unlike Miss Lipstadt, I don’t have access to a network with that kind of money.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Oh this is about money, is it? DEBORAH is shaking her head. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in. A BELL-BOY appears with a huge bunch of white lilies.

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: The manager wants you to have these. He’s wishing you luck.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you very much. I’m just asking, but in your country are white lilies lucky?

dialogues.speaker: BELLBOY
dialogues.text: I think so, yes.  75 76 77 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 54.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Just how in the States you usually see them on a grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH is turning her room into an operations centre: unpacking books, videotapes, files onto the desk. From th Sunday Times, she cuts out a photo of IRVING: “Irving Predicts Complete Victory”. She tapes it to the side of h computer screen. On the TV, Victoria Wood in Dinner Ladie DEBORAH looks bewildered at this most English of comedies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television in IRVING'S room is also playing Dinner Ladies. IRVING looks at it a moment, enjoying the humour. Then turns back to his desk to carry on his preparation. his computer a screen-grab of DEBORAH being humiliated at DeKalb. He works on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NETWORK REPORTERS are speaking straight to camera, from t middle of a pavement scrum - photographers, reporters.

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTER
dialogues.text: This morning will see the beginning of an extraordinary case in which a well-known historian and an obscure American academic will do battle to decide whether the Holocaust took place...

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTER 2
dialogues.text: Sources are saying that a whole network of supporters in the United States, including the film director Stephen Spielberg, are paying for Miss Lipstadt’s defence...

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTER 3
dialogues.text: ... Mr Irving is rumoured to have a list of over 4,000 contributors. They include a former U-boat captain who lives in Hawaii...

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTER 4
dialogues.text: It’s expected that this trial will be a long one, both sides digging in for a protracted fight... CAPTION: JANUARY 11th, 2000  78 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 55. On the opposite pavement, DEBORAH, dressed in coat and sc is amazed to see the scrum. Resolutely she starts crossin the road. The press has recognized her and is calling out ‘Deborah, Deborah’ and ‘Miss Lipstadt.’ She takes out a p of paper and turns to read from it. As she does, JULIUS a LAURA appear from nowhere like policemen.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Deborah. DEBORAH turns in surprise. JULIUS is wearing a black robe

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We wanted to make sure you didn’t go in alone.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: That’s sweet of you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: It’s not sweet at all. We wanted to make sure you didn’t speak.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: It’s just a short statement. Look, there’s Julie McCarthy, NPR... But he has already put his arm round her and LAURA has ta the other, manoeuvring her into the building. A man appea in front of DEBORAH’s face.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Lying Jewish bitch! But JULIUS has her quickly out of the way. As the MAN is hustled away by POLICE, he is heard shouting “Don’t think there’s anywhere to hide. We’re going to finish what Hitl started.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside they let go, and suddenly DEBORAH is all alone, looking at the amazing Gothic scale and splendour of the building. She’s awed, but her contemplation of it is disturbed by the arrival at the entrance of IRVING outsid lit by camera lights, the press surrounding him.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Good morning, everyone. I’m looking forward to this, if I may say a few words... She watches furious as the press write down everything he says. She catches up with JULIUS, with NIK and THOMAS carrying boxes of documents towards the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  79 80 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 56.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Did you see him? He’1l be all over the front pages...

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Deborah, there’s only one person who matters and that’s the judge. If you don’t speak in court and you do speak in the press, the judge is going to be furious. And rightly.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, we both know the answer to that. DEBORAH looks at JULIUS bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: And another thing. You jog the same way every day. Don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: I’m not saying anything. I’m just saying, vary your route. DEBORAH looks back outside. The angry MAN is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An obvious contrast: DEBORAH waiting on the left-hand sid the court which is full - DEBORAH now smiles at FORBES-WA who smiles back. RAMPTON is in wig and silk robe, alongsi JULIUS, LIBSON, HELENA, HEATHER and the team of researche led by LAURA. Stack upon stack of boxes and bundles of evidence. DEBORAH turns and looks up to the gallery. Some obvious Irving supporters - skinheads in T-shirts and tat and some less obvious - Aryan women and middle-aged men. she looks to the deserted opposite side as IRVING comes i papers under his arm, bare space all around. He puts his papers down in silence. JULIUS smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: David and Goliath. As advertised. IRVING suddenly turns and looks straight at DEBORAH. OK Corral - their look held. INT. JUDGE’S CHAMBERS. DAY 80 CHARLES GRAY, a suave, upper-class Englishman, 50s, in wi and gown is reading alone. The CLERK knocks on the door.  81 82 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 57.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sir, they’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Thank you. GRAY closes the book. It’s HITLER’S WAR by David Irving, covered in post-its and handwritten notes. GRAY finishes cup of tea then puts it down on a desk covered with evide submissions, video-tapes and tottering mountains of books gets up, nods at the CLERK and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAY sweeps along the corridor and into the court.

dialogues.speaker: COURT USHER
dialogues.text: Court rise. Everyone stands. GRAY takes his place. The whole court bo JULIUS whispers to DEBORAH.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Bow.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I’m American. Everything else but no bowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The court is packed except for the solitary area around IRVING. He is on his feet and addressing the judge eloquent, commanding, his hands mostly behind his back. DEBORAH is watching closely, trying to get his measure.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: My Lord, I intend to show that far from being a Holocaust denier, I have repeatedly drawn attention to major aspects of the Holocaust. These defendants have done very real damage to my professional existence. By virtue of the activities of Miss Lipstadt and those who funded her and guided her hand, since 1996 I have seen one fearful publisher after another falling away from me and turning their backs on me when I approach. My Lord, if we were to seek a title for this libel action, I would venture to suggest “Pictures at an Execution” - my execution.  83 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 58. RAMPTON, a compulsive cartoonist, is drawing IRVING in th side of a document. DEBORAH, looking round, sees an OLDER WOMAN, VERA REICH, small, upright, 70s, Polish, watching the public gallery.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These defendants did not act alone. They were part of an organized international endeavour to discredit me. The word ‘denier’ is particularly evil. The phrase is a poison to which there is virtually no antidote, less lethal than a hypodermic with nerve gas jabbed in the neck, but deadly all the same. For the chosen victim it is like being called a wife beater or a paedophile. It is enough for the label to be attached for the attachee to find himself designated as a pariah, an outcast from normal society. It is a verbal Yellow Star. IRVING has turned to look at DEBORAH, putting the accusat to her. DEBORAH stares back. RAMPTON’s cartoon shows IRVI hanging from a gallows, the noose captioned ‘Facts’. Underneath he has put the title “Pictures at an Execution

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recess. Everyone is pouring out of the court into the vau hall. DEBORAH is with LAURA, JULIUS and LIBSON.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: So, what you did think of him?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Irving? I thought he was oddly impressive.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Impressive? JULIUS smiles, patronising.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: The only thing that confused me.. It was like Irving already knew all our questions and points.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Yes of course. We sent them to him.  84 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 59.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You sent all our questions? In advance? I don’t get it. Isn’t that revealing our strategy?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Deborah, we have no strategy. We plan to box him in with the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH watches IRVING closely as RAMPTON rises to his fe at all times addressing GRAY, never once looking at IRVIN

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: My Lord, Mr Irving calls himself a historian. The truth, however, is that he is not a historian at all, but a falsifier of history. To put it bluntly, he is a liar. DEBORAH looks sharply across at RAMPTON, realising he is using her words. RAMPTON has two books in front of him, separate editions of HITLER'S WAR. He holds up the first then the second. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Between the publication of the first edition of Hitler’s War in 1977, and its second edition in 1991, Mr Irving’s views about the Holocaust underwent a sea-change. In 1977, he accepted it as a historical truth in all its essentials - systematic mass murder of the Jews in purpose-built extermination factories. But in the 1991 edition, all trace of the Holocaust in this sense has disappeared. What are the reasons for this astounding volte-face? The principal reason can be expressed in one word: Leuchter.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: The man with the dirty underwear. DEBORAH is so rapt she has spoken to herself. LIBSON shoo glance to JULIUS behind, who has also heard her.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: According to Mr Irving, the Leuchter report is “the biggest calibre shell that has yet hit the battleship Auschwitz”. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 60.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately for Mr Irving, the Leuchter report is bunk and he knows it. So why then did Mr Irving embrace the Leuchter report with such enthusiasm? Why did he choose to publish it himself and even to write an introduction? The answer must be that he wanted it to be true. After all if the Holocaust never happened, then Hitler cannot have ordered it or known about it.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: And that's the point. This time JULIUS puts a finger to his mouth to bid silenc RAMPTON picks up another piece of paper and reads from it

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: In September 1991 Mr Irving spoke to an audience in Calgary, Alberta. This is what he said: “I don’t see any reason to be tasteful about Auschwitz. It’s baloney. It’s a legend. Oh you think that’s tasteless? How about this? There are so many Auschwitz survivors going round, in fact their number increases as the years go past, that I’m going to form an association of Auschwitz Survivors, Survivors of the Holocaust and Other Liars called A-S-S-H-O-L-S, pronounced no doubt ‘asshols’...” RAMPTON puts down the paper. The court is silenced. Nobod moves. IRVING looks away, uninterested. RAMPTON (CONT’D) My Lord, this is obviously an important case. For if it be true that Mr Irving has devoted his energy to the deliberate falsification of this tragic episode in history, then by exposing that dangerous fraud in this court, the defendants may properly be applauded for having performed a significant public service, not just in this country but wherever in the world anti- Semitism and bigotry is waiting to be fed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzz as everyone flows out into the echoing space.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 61.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Wow! I thought we were pretty effective.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: That was a pretty good start.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: I’m glad you’re happy.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I saw his face. When we called him a liar. I don’t think he’s used to hearing things like that. It was exciting. VERA has put herself in DEBORAH'S way.

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Miss Lipstadt?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: May I speak to you?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I’1l1 catch up. DEBORAH has said this to JULIUS who hesitates, then goes

dialogues.speaker: VERA
dialogues.text: I want you to come and meet some of my friends. Friends with something in common. VERA rolls up her sleeve. A tattooed number. DEBORAH star

dialogues.speaker: VERA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We want to know: How can you let this happen? We don’t understand. How can it be happening? This is what you call a strategy? None of us have been called. We have to be heard. The voice of suffering has to be heard. A trial of the Holocaust and no witnesses? How can that be right? DEBORAH looks, her own doubts confirmed.

dialogues.speaker: VERA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a whole group of us. Deborah, we have to testify. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 87 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 62.

dialogues.speaker: VERA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have to. On behalf of the others. For the dead. DEBORAH nods slightly. They are in a quiet corner. She reaches out and touches VERA’S arm.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I make you a promise. The voice of suffering will be heard. It will. I promise you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH comes out into the roar of traffic. The others ha gone. She steps out and nearly gets run over by a bus, forgetting they drive on the left. A passerby calls out “Watch out!” A close thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH runs up the stairs and into chambers. It looks li party. LAURA, NIK, THOMAS, HEATHER etc. RAMPTON is openin filing cabinet and getting out a bottle of red wine.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I see this could well become a ritual. A welcome ritual, don't misunderstand. Deborah?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: A well-known Attorney General taught me very early on, one’s always a more effective advocate after a few glasses of claret. And some sandwiches. With a flourish, he opens a dusty cupboard and inside the are plates of cut sandwiches. Everyone laughs and piles i DEBORAH moves across to JULIUS in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you. It’s urgent. I’ve just spoken with a survivor.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Yes. Well that’s likely. I’ve seen several in the court. Someone hands JULIUS a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deborah, we’re not going to discuss this again.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 63.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: I’ve explained to you.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, the survivors are not on trial. That’s how it is. They confuse the issue. Keep them out of it. JULIUS has raised his voice. RAMPTON is alert to every wo but pretending not to listen.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You can look them in the face, can you, you can look survivors in the face and tell them they have no right to testify? They were there! They have the authority.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Deborah, these people came out of hell. I understand that. After all these years, they still haven't processed the experience. I know that too. But a trial, I’m afraid, isn’t therapy. Still less is it vindication. It isn’t our job to give emotional satisfaction to a whole lot of people who can never forget what happened to them.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You think they want to testify for themselves? They don’t give a damn about themselves. It’s the others. It’s their families. It’s their friends. If you were in their shoes, what would you feel? JULIUS just looks, not answering.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anthony, I promised them they would be heard. I made a promise.

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Well then you’d better go back out and break your promise. DEBORAH looks straight at him, then leaves.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH is sitting on the wall opposite, watching as the happy little team comes chattering out of RAMPTON’S chamb JULIUS, HEATHER, NIK, TOMAS, LAURA. She looks grim, alone They pass into the distance, chattering. But before they disappear, RAMPTON turns back, unseen, and looks at DEBOR 89 90 91 92 INT.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENAEUM HOTEL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: 89 DEBORAH, with boxes of Chinese takeout half-eaten, is watching one of her videos: scratchy film from 1962 of an MAN, HANS STARK, being interviewed. He speaks German, overlaid with an English interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: STARK, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: One day I was ordered to pour Zyklon B into the room because only one medical orderly had shown up. The Zyklon B was in granular form, so it trickled down over people as it poured in. Then they started to cry out terribly because they knew what was happening to them. After a few minutes, there was silence. DEBORAH stares. EXT.

dialogues.speaker: BIRKENAU. DAY
dialogues.text: 90 In her head DEBORAH sees a flash of what STARK is describ a slit of bright daylight as the hatch is opened, gas mas blue pellets pouring down touching bare flesh, a hatch slammed shut. Screams and cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIBBY is house-sitting. She is on the deck, legs in front her, in the dark. The Mutt is beside her.

dialogues.speaker: LIBBY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? You don’t sound happy. What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: How’s The Mutt?  93 94 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 65.

dialogues.speaker: LIBBY
dialogues.text: The Mutt’s lonely. He’s putting on a show but he’s not fooling anybody. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEBORAH is sitting on the side of the bed. Her room is an unvisited tip. She says nothing to LIBBY’S question.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 tell you what’s happening. Today one of the lawyers, the creepy one, told me if I’d promised anything to the survivors, I’d have to break my promise.

dialogues.speaker: LIBBY
dialogues.text: He said that?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Libby, I arrived in London, I thought ‘These men know best, it’s their country, it’s their system.’ I’m with a lot of people who understand the facts. They know all the facts. But God knows where they keep their hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT JAN is in the witness box. He has toned down the colour of his hair and he has a perfect three-piece suit. Arranged on easels are large colour photographs of Birken and Auschwitz. Beside them are black and white drawings o the gas chamber interior. IRVING is examining him.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: May I first of all welcome you to our country and say what a great pleasure I had in reading your book on Auschwitz. You were deeply moved to visit the actual location?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: More than moved. I was frightened. It's an awesome responsibility. DEBORAH looks to the gallery. VERA’S look back is unwaver

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Professor van Pelt, would you agree it is the duty of historians to remain completely unemotional?  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 66.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: One’s duty is to be unemotional, to be objective, but one's duty I think is to remain human in the exercise. IRVING nods, as if this is just something JAN has to say.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: The site of Auschwitz has not changed very much since the end of World War 2, apart from the barracks being torn down and re- cycled. Can you explain to the court, please, why it is that in the very earliest references to Auschwitz published by the Russians after the capture of the camp in January 1945, there is no reference whatsoever to the discovery of gas chambers?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: I would need to see the documents you refer to.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: That’s fair, I think. IRVING smiles tolerantly at the judge’s interruption.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: It is fair, my Lord. Your report quotes extensively from first-hand testimony from a man called Tauber.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT JAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Tauber was a Sonderkommando in Crematorium Number 2. He helped with the prisoners, he was in charge of roll call.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: In charge of roll call, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: I had to.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I understand that now.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: You were preparing a case. You had to be sure. However disrespectful you seemed. However heartless.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Of course. That’s what I do. RAMPTON looks at her. He is very moved. RAMPTON (CONT’D) I had no idea what to expect. It was a brief. Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 85. DEBORAH acknowledges this silently. RAMPTON (CONT’D) It’s painful for me to watch a client in such distress. We didn’t set out to make you unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Well? DEBORAH hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I never trusted anyone to do anything. Since I was a child. All I have is my voice, my conscience. Just that. And I have to listen to it.

In 1941, he called Heydrich from Hitler's bunker to give him instructions. After the call he wrote some words. “Judentransport aus Berlin. Keine Liquidierung.” Which clearly means “The Jew Transport from Berlin. No liquidation.” For emphasis he repeats the line slowly.

dialogues.speaker: EVANS, (CONT'D)

RAMPTON (CONT’D) Mr Irving, next I want to refer you to a talk you gave to the Clarendon Club, whatever that may be, on 19th September 1992. The transcripts. Tab 5, My Lord, page 35.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY

dialogues.speaker: IRVING, (VIDEO)

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Trevor McDonald.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 92.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

dialogues.text: Well in fact this is a stock speech I used to make. I would say “In the good old days, the announcer used to wear a dinner jacket, but now they have women reading the news, and they have -”" it’s part of a general speech.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: IRVING, (VIDEO)

For the time being, I would be prepared to accept that the BBC should have a dinner- jacketed gentleman reading all the important news, followed by a lady reading all the less important news. Followed by Trevor McDonald giving all the latest news about muggings and drug busts. RAMPTON turns the video off.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: “Rest lost in loud laughter and applause.” Are you not appalled by that?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Not in the least. This is a witty speech delivered after dinner to an audience in a private club.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: ‘Witty’, did you say?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Well, it got laughter.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 93.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: No doubt. As Dr Goebbels’ audience would have laughed at him. LAURA is watching intently, appalled. DEBORAH looks down the familiar cartoon in front of her, and for the first t looks not at her own gagged figure but at RAMPTON leading charge. She smiles to herself. RAMPTON (CONT’D) “I am not anti-coloured, take it from me. Nothing pleases me more than when I arrive at an airport and I see a coloured family there - When I see black families arriving at the airport I am happy. And when I see them leaving at London airport I am happy.” Well, Mr Irving? Well? IRVING shrugs, as if it were nothing.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: I think we all dislike tourists of any colour.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Tourists? These are black people. You were speaking to a bunch of racists.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: No I was not. They were perfectly ordinary guests at a...

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

dialogues.speaker: IRVING

Jessica...” Who is Jessica?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON

On those walks we sing the binkety-bankety-bong song. There is a silence. RAMPTON puts the document down. DEBOR is open-mouthed in disbelief. RAMPTON (CONT’D) Racist, Mr Irving? Anti-Semitic, Mr Irving?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: I do not think so.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Teaching your little child this kind of poison?

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Do you think a nine month old can understand words spoken in English or any other language?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: The poor little child has been taught a racist ditty by her perverted racist father.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Have you ever read Edward Lear or Hilaire Belloc?  125 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 95.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: They have not brought a libel action, Mr Irving. You have. Mr Irving, you sued because you said we called you a racist and an extremist.

dialogues.speaker: IRVING
dialogues.text: Yes, but I am not a racist. RAMPTON is finished. He does not even look at IRVING.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Mr Irving, look at the words on the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole gang coming out together - DEBORAH, RAMPTON, LA JULIUS, LIBSON etc. They are high as kites.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That was good stuff...

dialogues.speaker: LIBSON
dialogues.text: Well done, there it is. Anti- Semitism, racism, holocaust denial: we always said it was a package didn’t we? Symptoms, motive, purpose. What else do they want? DEBORAH looks at JULIUS who is impassive.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: What did you think, Anthony?

dialogues.speaker: JULIUS
dialogues.text: Think? I thought nothing. Much the most boring morning we've had in court so far.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH

dialogues.speaker: NETWORK REPORTERS
dialogues.text: This trial has been both long, now running for almost eight weeks and hugely expensive. Its cost is currently estimated at over three million pounds. Some are saying this trial raises serious issues for freedom of speech. Now only the two summings-up remain before the judge, Charles Gray QC, retires for what we are told will be at least four weeks to consider his verdict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court overflowing now. RAMPTON comes across to DEBORA

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Is your survivor friend in the court?

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: Why? DEBORAH nods up to VERA sitting in her place. RAMPTON put his hand on her arm, then moves across to address the cou

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: My Lord, I start with this, that if one had read some of the media reports, one might have supposed that Mr Irving had been dragged into this court to defend his freedom of speech. The history of the matter is quite the reverse. The defendant did make serious charges. But, as it turns out from the evidence, the accusations are true in every significant respect. RAMPTON shares a look with DEBORAH before continuing. He really wants her to hear this. RAMPTON (CONT’D) The Holocaust took place in stages. The first stage, beginning in 1941, consisted of mass shootings carried out by specially formed SS groups and their local allies. DEBORAH closes her eyes. There is a moment as the faces o multitude of people are shown on the walls of the court, if the ghosts of the dead were present.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 98. RAMPTON (CONT’D) This resulted in the deaths of up to 1.5 million Jews living in Russia and the Baltic States. The second stage, which began in December 1941, consisted of the gassing of Jews of the Warthegau and Poland. This resulted in the deaths of probably as many as 2.6 million. The third stage, beginning with mass deportations in 1941, culminated in the gassing, mostly at Auschwitz, of Jews from Central, Western and Southern Europe. This stage lasted until late 1944. At this point RAMPTON looks to DEBORAH then turns and loo up to the gallery where VERA and the other SURVIVORS are sitting. He addresses them. RAMPTON (CONT’D) The total achievement of this systematic mass murder was probably between five and six million innocent souls. RAMPTON bows imperceptibly to VERA who stares back, moved The multitude disappears. DEBORAH watches, not breathing. RAMPTON (CONT’D) It is wildly implausible therefore to present Adolf Hitler as a somewhat harried business executive, too preoccupied to know what was happening in the branch offices in Treblinka and Auschwitz. During this trial we have heard from Professor Evans and others of at least twenty five major falsifications of history. Well, says Mr Irving, all historians make mistakes. But there is a difference between negligence, which is random in its effect and a deliberateness which is far more one-sided. All Mr Irving's little fictions, all his tweaks of the evidence, all tend in the same direction: exculpation of Adolf Hitler. It is, to use an analogy, like a waiter who always gives the wrong change. If the waiter is honest, then we may expect his mistakes sometimes to benefit the customer, sometimes himself. But Mr Irving is the dishonest waiter. Every one of his mistakes works in his own favour.  Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 99. For once at the trial DEBORAH smiles. RAMPTON (CONT’D) How far, if at all, Mr Irving's anti-Semitism is a cause of his Hitler apology, or vice versa, is unimportant. Whether they are taken together or individually it is clear they have led him to prostitute his reputation as a serious historian for the sake of a bogus rehabilitation of Hitler, and the dissemination of virulent anti- Semitic propaganda. GRAY stirs at this point.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Yes, this is a question I have to ask you, Mr Rampton.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: By all means, my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: My question is this: if somebody is anti-Semitic, anti-Semitic and extremist, he is perfectly capable of being honestly anti-Semitic? Yes? He is holding those views and expressing those views because they are indeed his views. RAMPTON is thrown, unsteady, bewildered by the question.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: And so it seems to me, if it comes down to it, that the anti-Semitism is a completely separate allegation which has precious little bearing on your broader charge that he has manipulated the data?

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: No, my Lord. No. The whole endeavour of the defence has been to prove that the two are connected.

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Yes, but he might believe what he is saying. That is the point. That is why it’s important.  129 Full Blue Script // December 4th 2015 100. DEBORAH looks to JULIUS, who looks equally alarmed. For a moment, RAMPTON is lost.

dialogues.speaker: RAMPTON
dialogues.text: My Lord, if we know for a fact that Mr Irving is an anti-Semite, and if we also know that there is no historical justification for Holocaust denial, then surely it’s not a great stretch to see the two things must be connected?

dialogues.speaker: GRAY
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. Carry on. DEBORAH turns again to JULIUS, who is shaking his head.

dialogues.text: What the fuck just happened? JULIUS looks to RAMPTON, for the first time fear in his e INT & EXT. DEBORAH’S HOUSE. dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course I’m not sure he realised when he agreed to a trial by a single judge, that it would mean a written judgement. This judgement’s going to stand against him forever. There are some flashes, more questions. DEBORAH motors on through them, the flood-gates are open at last.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now some people fear that the only effect of this trial will be to close down free speech. I don’t accept that. I’m not attacking free speech. On the contrary. I’ve been defending it against someone who wanted to abuse it. People can be as sceptical as they like. What they can’t be is dishonest. Freedom of speech doesn’t include freedom to get away with lying. Not all opinions are equal. Some things do happen, just like we’re told they do. Slavery happened. The black death happened. The world is round. The ice-caps are melting. Elvis is dead.

It turns out, it’s not a bad place as long as you have great lawyers. With great passion. And boy, did I have great lawyers. RAMPTON is standing at the back, next to LAURA.
